titleStmt.title: Further Studies on Control Synthesis of Discrete-Time T-S Fuzzy Systems via Useful Matrix Equalities

affiliation.orgName: Huazhong University of Science and Technology

analytic.title: Further Studies on Control Synthesis of Discrete-Time T-S Fuzzy Systems via Useful Matrix Equalities

biblStruct.note: This article has been accepted for publication in a future issue of this journal, but has not been fully edited. Content may change prior to final publication.

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: This short paper is concerned with further studies on control synthesis of discrete-time nonlinear systems in the Takagi-Sugeno fuzzy form. To do this, a novel slack variable technique is presented by developing some useful matrix inequalities which are homogenous polynomially parameter-dependent on both the current-time normalized fuzzy weighting functions and the past-time normalized fuzzy weighting functions. Under the framework of homogenous matrix polynomials, the algebraic properties of both the current-time normalized fuzzy weighting functions and the past-time normalized fuzzy weighting functions are collected for the first time into a sets of united collection matrices. Consequently, the relaxation quality of control synthesis of discrete-time T-S fuzzy systems is improved, i.e., the convergence of asymptotically necessary and sufficient stabilization conditions is further sped up. Finally, a numerical example is provided to illustrate the effectiveness of the proposed result.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: Recently, Takagi-Sugeno fuzzy model proposed in [1] has attracted great attention since it is an effective way to transform a nonlinear system into a set of linear sub-models. More importantly, it has been proved by using the Stone-Weierstrass theorem that the fuzzy basis functions are capable of uniformly approximating to any real function on a compact set to arbitrary accuracy [2]. One of the first control schemes proposed in T-S fuzzy systems was the parallel distributed compensation (PDC) method [3]. In the PDC method, the controller shares the same fuzzy rules and sets as the T-S system. However, most of earlier results are based on common Lyapunov functions and the the PDC method, which often lead to very conservative results [4]. Thus, much effort has been devoted to relaxed stability/stabilization conditions by either developing efficient slack variable techniques or exploiting the algebraic property of normalized fuzzy weighting functions(see e.g. [4]- [8]). To further reduce the conservatism, many general classes of Lyapunov functions have been developed, including piecewise quadratic Lyapunov functions [9]- [11], non-quadratic Lyapunov functions [12]- [17]. Especially, the powerful Non-parallel distributed compensation (Non-PDC) control scheme was proposed to obtain stabilization conditions in LMI formulations [12]. Some extended non-PDC control schemes and more general non-quadratic Lyapunov functions are proposed in [13]- [17]. Another approach called the k-samples variation exists to reduce these pessimistic results in [18] and extended in [19] and [20]. Considering a k-samples variation using a given Lyapunov function is equivalent to the case with considering a 1-sample variation approach using an extended Lyapunov function [19].

On the other hand, the homogenous polynomially parameter-dependent (HPPD) solutions proposed in [21] have been applied to deal with the problem of stability analysis of uncertain linear time-invariant(LTI) systems in the polytopic domain. Unlike to uncertain LTI systems with unknown parameters belong to a convex bounded uncertain domain, an important feature for T-S fuzzy systems is that the normalized fuzzy weighting functions are measurable on-line, and hence it provides a chance to achieve relaxed stabilization conditions by means of designing novel fuzzy control schemes via the HPPD solutions. Recently, the HPPD solutions have been extended to cope with control synthesis of discrete/continuoustime T-S fuzzy systems [22]- [26]. For control synthesis of discrete-time T-S fuzzy systems, asymptotically necessary and sufficient (ANS) stabilization conditions of discrete-time T-S fuzzy systems have been proposed in [23] by generalizing the procedure based on Polya's theorem. More recently, a new slack variable technique which suits the homogenous polynomial setting has been developed in [26], and the algebraic properties of the current-time normalized fuzzy weighting functions are collected into a sets of united collection matrices to speed up the convergence of ANS stabilization conditions. Indeed, it is not proper to say "less conservative stabilization conditions are obtained in [26] than the result given in [23]" without any restriction on the statement. It could be corrected as follows: the relaxation quality of ANS stabilization conditions has been improved in [26], i.e., [26] improves [23] for the same pair of {p, d 1 , d 2 } and the convergence of ANS stabilization conditions is sped up.

Motivated by the aforementioned observations, this short paper is towards further exploring the potentialities of HPPD solutions in control synthesis of discrete-time T-S fuzzy systems. By using some useful matrix inequalities, a novel slack variable technique is developed under the framework of homogenous matrix polynomials. The algebraic properties of both the current-time normalized fuzzy weighting functions and the past-time normalized fuzzy weighting functions are collected into a sets of united collection matrices. Compared with the result proposed in [26], the algebraic properties of both the current-time normalized fuzzy weighting functions and the past-time normalized fuzzy weighting functions are fully considered, and hence more flexibility could be introduced to improve the relaxation quality, i.e., the convergence of ANS stabilization conditions is further sped up and more efficient stabilization conditions are obtained. Finally, a numerical example is provided to illustrate the effectiveness of the proposed result.

div.head: B. Existing relaxed stabilization conditions via a recent Non-PDC control scheme and a useful lemma
div.p: Consider a class of discrete-time nonlinear system described by the following T-S fuzzy model:
div.formula: Rule i: If z 1 (m) is F i 1 , and z 2 (m) is F i 2 , • • • , and z p (m) is F i p , Then x(m + 1) = A i x(m) + B i u(m), i ∈ {1, 2, ..., r} where m ∈ N, x(m) ∈ R n1 is the state vector, u(m) ∈ R n2
div.p: is the control input, and z j (m) is the premise variable of the system.
By using product of inference, singleton fuzzifier, and center-average defuzzifier, the defuzzified output of the overall discrete-time T-S fuzzy model can be represented as [1]:
div.formula: x(m + 1) = r ∑ i=1 h i (z(m))(A i x(m) + B i u(m)). (3
div.p: where h i (z(m)) denotes the i-th normalized fuzzy weighting function with the property of h i (z(m)) ≥ 0 and ∑ r i=1 h i (z(m)) = 1 without loss of generality.
For simplicity, we use the following shortenings in the sequel:
Recently, a new Non-PDC control scheme has been designed in [26] for stabilizing the discrete-time T-S fuzzy system (3) :

div.head: III. MAIN RESULTS
div.p: Theorem 1. Consider the discrete-time T-S fuzzy system (3) and the Non-PDC control scheme (4). For given g ∈ Z + , d 1 ∈ N and d 2 ∈ N with g + d 1 -2 > 0 and g + d 2 -1 > 0, the closed-loop fuzzy system is globally asymptotically stable, if there exist symmetric matrices
div.formula: P k ∈ R n×n (k ∈ K(g)); matrices F k ∈ R q×n , G k ∈ R n×n (k ∈ K(g)); symmetric matrices R iik mmq with q ∈ K(g+d 1 -2), k ∈ K(g+d 2 -1), m = 1, ..., r and i = 1, ..., r; matrices R ijk mmq = (R jik mmq ) T with q ∈ K(g+d 1 -2), k ∈ K(g+d 2 -1), m = 1, ..., r and 1 ≤ i < j ≤ r; matrices R iik mnq = (R iik mnq ) T with q ∈ K(g+d 1 -2), k ∈ K(g + d 2 -1), i = 1, ..., r and 1 ≤ m < n ≤ r; matrices R ijk mnq = (R jik nmq ) T with q ∈ K(g + d 1 -2), k ∈ K(g + d 2 -1), 1 ≤ m ≤ r, 1 ≤ n ≤ r, m ̸ = n and 1 ≤ i < j ≤ r,
div.p: such that the following LMIs ( 14)-( 15) hold:

By summing all possible inequalities which satisfy (20), we can obtain ∑ k∈K(g+d2+1),p∈K(g+d1)

div.p: Applying Lemma 2 to (21), and combining ( 17)-( 19), we have
div.formula: Π = ∑ k∈K(g+d2+1),p∈K(g+d1) h k (h + ) p Γ pk > 0. (22
div.p: Thus, from (22) and Lemma 1, it could be concluded that the closed-loop fuzzy system is globally asymptotically stable under the LMI-based conditions ( 14)- (15).
Remark 1: The total number of scalar decision variables (N d ) and the total row size of solved LMIs ( 14)-( 15) (N l ) can be calculated as
and
and
By the standard approach, the computational complexity of the LMI optimization problem can be estimated as being proportional to log 10
div.formula: ( N 3 d N l )
div.p: . A table to compare the computational complexity for various values of the scalars (g, d 1 , d 2 ) will be given in the next section. It is worth noting that the computational complexity will increase as the value of g, d 1 or d 2 increases. However, practical applications of the proposed result could be summarized as follows:
Step 1) representing nonlinear controlled systems by using T-S fuzzy model (3);
Step 2) selecting proper values of g, d 1 and d 2 , and then solving LMIs ( 14)-(15) off-line;
Step 3) implementing the Non-PDC control scheme (4) on-line for control synthesis of practical nonlinear systems.

Fortunately, most of the additional computational complexity takes place in Step 2, which is only required to be calculated off-line and without strict real time requirement, i.e., the proposed result can be practically applied to a real world application for various control designs of T-S fuzzy control [27], [28].

div.head: IV. NUMERICAL EXAMPLES
div.p: A well-known numerical example is given here to illustrate the effectiveness of the proposed result.
Example: Consider the following discrete-time nonlinear model with

With Theorem 1 of [23], Theorem 1 of [26] and Theorem 1 of this paper being applied, the maximum feasible values of β are calculated while several pairs of (g, d 1 , d 2 ) are selected respectively. These results are listed in Table I. From Table I, it is easy to see that Theorem 1 of this paper provides the largest stabilization region than two existing ones given in [23] and [26] for fixed pair of (g, d 1 , d 2 ). By the standard approach, the off-line computational complexity of the LMI optimization problem can be estimated as being proportional to log 10 (
div.formula: N 3 d N l
div.p: . Table II is given to compare the off computational complexity for various values of the scalars (g, d 1 , d 2 ). For β = 1.77, the underlying closed-loop systems could be stabilized for Theorem 1 of [26] with g ≥ 3 (required at least 8 on-line control variables), and it also could be stabilized for Theorem 1 of this paper with g = 2 (required only 6 on-line control variables), i.e., the convergence of ANS stabilization conditions is further sped up. This fact illustrates that the relaxation quality of control synthesis of discrete-time T-S fuzzy systems is improved due to the usage of the approach in this paper. Step The trajectories of J(m) Control scheme proposed in [26] Control scheme proposed in this paper Fig. 1.

Response curves of performance index function J(m) via two different fuzzy control schemes From the above analysis, one can conclude that the relaxation quality of control synthesis of discrete-time T-S fuzzy systems is improved than the one given in [26]. Next, the comparison results on control performance will also be illustrated, i.e., with the same system parameters β, the responses of both the system state variables and the control inputs via different control schemes are compared with each other. Borrowed from [26], the criterion is selected as a classical quadratic performance index function:
div.formula: J(m) = m ∑ i=1 ( x T (i)x(i) + u T (i)u(i) ) . (23
div.p: For β = 1.68, using Theorem 1 in this paper also with (g = 2, d 1 = 1, d 2 = 1), the control gain matrices of the Non-PDC control scheme (4) are calculated as follows: .49] T and using the control scheme in [26] and the control scheme of this paper, the responses of the performance index function J(m) via the above two control schemes are shown in Fig. 1. From Fig. 1, one can conclude that the performance index by the control scheme of this paper is superior to the counterpart one proposed in [26].

Next, for β = 1.81, it can be found that both approaches given in [23] and [26] with g, d 1 , d 3 ≤ 3 fail to provide feasible stabilization conditions. However, by using Theorem 1 in this paper with (g = 2, d 1 = 1, d 2 = 1), the control gain matrices of the Non-PDC control scheme (4) are calculated as follows: Choosing x(0) = [1.81, 2.49] T and using the obtained control scheme, the resultant state responses are shown in Fig. 2. From Fig. 2, it is easy to see that the closed-loop system is globally asymptotically stable under the control of the obtained control scheme.

div.head: V. CONCLUSION
div.p: In this paper, the problem of improving the relaxation quality of control synthesis for discrete-time T-S fuzzy systems has been addressed. By using some useful matrix inequalities, more algebraic properties of both the current-time fuzzy weighting functions and the past-time normalized fuzzy weighting functions are collected into a sets of united collection matrices. Thus, the convergence of ANS stabilization conditions is further sped up and more efficient stabilization conditions are obtained. A numerical example has also been provided to illustrate the effectiveness of the proposed result.
